I don’t get the notification on discord, and I noticed lately that sesh bot doesn’t notify as at when due, it’s a bit late while giving notifications these days.Is there a solution to that

Hey, @Freakytainment, do you have the ‘meetings’ discord channel notifications on? They notify ~10 minutes before the call begins. Also, you can turn on notifications for the Discourse subtag ‘pubcall-:-governance-and-risk’ and on the top right corner will be a bell that can turn on notifications for all new posts and post updates for these G&R calls. Lmk!
I think the discourse would be much better because I’m active on that than the discord. Thanks.

Episode #214: November 3rd, 2022 | Editorial Summary  Agenda   00:00: Introduction  1:46: Votes and Polls  3:37: MIPs Update  7:15: Weekly Forum Recap  12:18: Initiatives Update: GUSD Partnership Update  13:47 Discussion: Crimson Cluster  30:55: Discussion: Viridian Cluster  00:00: Conclusion   Video Link  General Updates  Votes  Patrick_J 1:46 Visit: Voting Portal  Votes:   Polls: – 1:50   Executive Proposals: – 2:39     MIPs  Gala 3:37 Visit: Weekly MIPs Update #111 MakerDAO Votes and Polls Public Calendar Important Dates: Formal Submission Window Opens Nov 7th. New Proposals must be posted Dec 7th  Proposals in RFC:   Core Unit Budgets – 3:48   Top Level MIPs – 4:19   Other Subproposals – 5:26     Weekly Forum Recap  Artem Gordon 7:15  Visit: Weekly Forum Recap: October 27th - November 2nd, 2022  News & Announcements:  Technical Update for the 2nd November Executive Starknet Bridge Upgrade Forum Maintenance Announcement    Discussion:  Fall of HUSD & Lessons for Maker Drinks w/ Delegates: Endgame MetaDAO Scaling ft. Nadia    Initiatives Update  GUSD Partnership Update  Sebastian Derivaux 12:18     GUSD & MakerDAO Partnership Announcement Integrations       Hi to all the members of the Maker community!  In order to deepen our partnership with Maker, we have been working closely with the Strategic Finance Core Unit and the Growth Core Unit to understand how Gemini can contribute to strengthening the Maker ecosystem. We came up with the below proposal and look forward to hearing the community’s feedback!  For more context and information on the support of Maker by Gemini our original GUSD PSM proposal can be found here: Proposal: GUSD PSM  The Gemini…      Gemini has approved the payment flow for the rewards. Funds will be received in December and transferred directly to MakerDAO without needing a legal entity. They will pay an annual rate of 1.25%.   Discussion  Crimson Cluster  hexonaut  717×402 68.9 KB  14:46  We want to work with other crypto projects, vertically incorporate them under MKR, and support DAI as a first-class citizen. Our first project is an advanced money market.  16:09  Q&A  2326×1276 188 KB  20:17   Patrick_J: Do you have plans for cross-chain as part of Crimson?   Hexonaut: Absolutely!! We need to get multi-chain support for accounting and the vault engine.    22:17   ElPro: How do you plan to implement ALM strategies?   Hexonaut: We have yet to think much about this, but it’s something to consider in the future.    24:28   Matt: How do you jump-start the community of token holders for the Creator DAO beyond farming? Is there a natural fit for community contributors?   Hexonaut: Some may farm for speculation, others for community engagement. The initial release will offer the best features and rates within the market to bootstrap everything.    26:08   Tim Black: Are you having algorithmic rates for the lending engine?   Hexonaut: Yes, for the lending engine. However, for the collaterals, we will use other lending markets like Aave, Compound, etc.    27:30   ElPro: How does your cluster envision ecosystem actors helping out both within and outside?   Hexonaut: The team is meant to be administrative, where we pool these actors together. We will be contracting them.    30:11   David Utrobin: Is Crimson Cluster expecting to be its MetaDAO? Do you plan to join others?   Hexonaut: Standalone MetaDAO.     Discussion  Viridian Cluster  Alan Peterson 30:57 Viridian Cluster Overview Presentation:  725×403 180 KB   726×408 123 KB   729×409 68.6 KB   727×410 77.5 KB   729×404 223 KB   728×409 104 KB   730×408 166 KB   729×408 122 KB   730×411 98.5 KB   730×407 49.9 KB   731×411 94.8 KB   722×412 192 KB   729×406 168 KB   836×412 69.7 KB   Q&A  2483×1380 221 KB  47:29   ElPro: How is your cluster thinking on the possibility of going risk-on and partnering with arrangers who go after riskier opportunities?   Allan: If there’s capital for that, we will try to do that. At the moment, given the current situation, we will not be increasing the risk.    51:25   ElPro: How do you plan on hedging risk for the residential mortgage-backed securities when exposed to it via arrangers?  57:26   David Utrobin: Given the current environment, why not go all-in to earn over 4% with minimal risk?   Sebastian: We could, but the potential problem is that we will have to give back part of this cash flow by increasing the DSR.    1:00:36   David Kret: All these MIPs are in Maker Core. How do you envision vault adoption taking place from a technical perspective?   Allan: We’re still determining. We know it will take place, but the technical features will be developed over the next months. These are still very early stages.    1:01:50   David Utrobin: To what extent can you be a true DAO while engaging with entities and regulators?  1:10:16   David Utrobin: Is the Viridian Cluster responsible for risk assessments regarding its RWA deals?   Rajiv: I believe so, but we are only a few weeks in and building the team for this.    1:11:35   David Utrobin: Is the Viridian Cluster intending to be its metaDAO?   Allan: If we can all find a good way to work together, there’s an opportunity for cross-cluster sharing. But Viridian can work on its methods for asset management strategies to support DAI stability and growth.    1:14:56   David Utrobin: Has anyone considered what happens to the protocol if any of the ‘horses’ go insolvent?   Allan: We’ve built it to be highly unlikely. However, each arrangement is very solid and has a very low probability of losing a large amount of value.    Suggestion Box  Credits  Artem Gordon produced this summary. Larry Wu produced this summary. Everyone who spoke and presented on the call.

Episode #215: November 10th, 2022 | Editorial Summary  Agenda   0:00: Introduction  3:04: Votes and Polls  4:20: MIPs Update  7:25: Weekly Forum Recap  10:00: Discussion: Defender Contracts Against Gov Attacks  42:28: Discussion: Modify Emulated SB Upper Limit  1:13:24: Conclusion   Video Link  General Updates  Votes  Payton Rose 3:04 Visit: Voting Portal  Votes:   Polls: – 3:07   Executive Proposals: – 3:18     MIPs  Pablo 4:27 Visit: Weekly MIPs Update #112 & MakerDAO Votes and Polls Public Calendar Important Dates: New proposals must be posted by Wednesday, December 7th, at the latest, to be eligible for the next monthly cycle.  Formal Submissions:   Top-Level MIPs – 4:47   Core Unit Budgets – 5:04   Miscellaneous – 5:21     Proposals in RFC:   Top-Level MIPs – 5:51   Miscellaneous – 6:11     Weekly Forum Recap  Artem Gordon 07:20  Visit: Weekly Forum Recap: November 3rd - November 9th, 2022  Video: Link  News & Announcements:  Build Your Own ALM Model    Research:  Vault User Research: Survival Analysis    Discussion  MIP91: Defender Contract Against Governance Attacks  David Utrobin 10:39  MIP91 is a new smart contract addition to our existing governance system that gives MKR holders another tool to defend against malicious attacks. It enables canceling a past executive vote waiting to be executed within the GSM pause delay.   1630×712 180 KB  13:31   Astro: The purpose of this MIP is to defend Maker against Governance attacks: where the attacker has enough MKR to take over and pass potentially malicious executives.  The distribution of MKR could end up concentrated in a few people’s hands. When there is a potential attack, there will be misinformation. If we can stop a malicious executive without shutting down the protocol, that would be preferred. TLDR version: if MKR holders think Maker is under governance attack, and the hat cannot be retaken, they can deposit their own MKR into a contract called DSS Defender. Some threshold amount needs to be deposited before the contract is activated, and it can only be triggered once. Once the threshold is reached, the protocol is locked into its current state.    21:12   Prose11: Why delegates can’t we use the defender contractor for the lockup in particular?   Astro: I wanted a version where delegates could use it. However, we currently have a liquid delegation, which causes issues between delegates and delegators regarding the penalty of MIP91.    22:58   ultraschuppi: How can you lock your MKR and Dss Defender and put it into the emergency shutdown module?   Astro: You can’t move it to any address except the ESM.    23:34   David Utrobin: Can DSS Defender delay an executive multiple times?   Astro: If the attacker has the hat, they will spam multiple execs. The Dss Defender will cancel all of them permissionlessly.    24:20   David Utrobin: Is it correct that after the cancel duration, the DSS Defender Auto redeploys itself?   Astro: That’s not true. Check MIP91c3: Post-activation Permissions and Events on the forum for more information.    25:58   David Utrobin: Do delegates or other stakeholders have any cons on their minds about this?   Derek: An attack where PE deploys a fix to an existing vulnerability where an attacker can reverse engineer the vulnerability by looking at PE’s fix within 48 hours. They can deposit MKR into the defender as well.    27:17   David Utrobin: Can’t the DSS Defender contract be designed in a way where it cancels all except some?   Astro: You would end up trusting governance in that case.    35:35   Prose11: How likely is such an attack in the first place that e have seen attacks like these?  In terms of severe attacks, the answer is no. If we were ever in this scenario, our only option is the ESM, which would ripple throughout the entire industry.     Discussion  MIP84c10-SP1: Modify Emulated SB Upper Limit 42:32  Overview1588×803 141 KB   1033×1016 160 KB   1069×1012 129 KB  47:35   Psychonaut: The idea is to change the defaults from the current proposal to a proposal that does not envision immediately taking on considerable leverage.  53:06   Chat: The Starting Capital defines the DC. The initial 20m would be divided by 1.25 to define the Lower Limit. If there is some Excess Dai which is the remaining amount of Dai in the Surplus Buffer, and if there is something about the Upper Limit, this Excess Dai will effectively become part of the Starting Capital.  57:19   Psychonaut: The Collateral Ratio defines the Lower Limit. And because there is a sub-proposal to change the Collateral Ratio, the Lower Limit can also be changed by it.   David Utrobin: If the Upper Limit was set high to the point where we do not have Excess Dai. Does it mean we would have zero Starting Collateral?  Psychonaut: No, because Starting collateral is defined as its parameter.  Payton Rose: Once that happens, if the Upper Limit does not change, the initial MIP suggested is at 40 million Dai, so if we accrue more than that in our Surplus Buffer, we would be automatically expecting to lever it back in. If you raise the Upper Limit, then that re-up levering would only happen at the Risk CU’s direct wishes, which is mandated with overseeing this and giving monthly reports.    1:00:07:   Payton Rose: As the proposal author, why do you feel more comfortable with Dai emulating as the Surplus Buffer instead of a leveraged ETH position for backing Dai?   Psychonaut: If we have a leveraged position in stETH, we risk the protocol becoming insolvent. We have a Surplus Buffer to sustain losses if some of the collateral goes bad and does not become insolvent. If we have the Surplus Buffer in Dai, we know that buffer against losses will be there when needed. If it is stETH, then we do not know.    1:02:07   PaperImperium: I would like to see an effort to define and separate Dai held as loss reserves.   monet-supply: The flip side of the scenario is that Maker’s capital at risk tends to increase in bull markets.  ElPro: People who are fully sitting on ETH are much more comfortable than those sitting on other things. If you are holding ETH, you are not feeling much pain. This helps build a lot of DAI backing into decentralized collateral. It gets away from the addiction of being backed by USDC and others.    1:05:21   Payton Rose: ETH is super collateral. Liquid State Derivatives will play a huge part in this ecosystem going forward, and getting your hands o a bunch of them sooner rather than later could prove quite lucrative. It is also powerful to keep in mind that these are yield-bearing assets.   Psychonaut: stETH is a great asset, but it is one thing to invest in that asset without leverage, and another thing is to invest it with leverage. If you are trying to keep your loss reserve safe, then you do not use leverage.  ElPro: You have to weigh what risks you want to take and how safely you want to think. With the lower mint and the upper mint, and with the risk involved and analyzing it, it is worth giving it a try. There is a lot that still needs to be figured out.    1:07:57   Payton Rose: Why did you pursue raising the Upper Limit instead of trying to stop this entirely from happening?   Psychonaut: I was tempted to stop it from happening, but there seems to be a lot of momentum and interest in support of Rune’s idea, and I want to respect that. It was the minor change I could make to reduce the risk that Maker would be taking on with the POVE.    1:10:40   Payton Rose: This Vault Engine is still being developed. Some technical aspects might force our understanding to change slightly, but this is the intention of Rune’s MIP and what the DAO will be trying to carry out since it was passed.   Derek: The technical work is already known. It is ordered, so we will see what comes back, pending any feedback from it.    1:13:56   Robert: Quick update that relates to MIP 81. We are trying to confirm and evaluate the timing of the two solutions’ overhead. There is the one listed in the MIP and the one with the smart contract. The smart contract approach continues to lead with a shorter overall implementation time and reduces risk in managing USDC. PE has reviewed and provided feedback on the smart contract. Again, indications are that the smart contract approach is faster than finding a new arranger, which is the traditional custodial approach. With the smart contract approach, no monies are transferred in the real world, allowing us to use an existing arranger like Monetalis and formalize the arrangement with Coinbase.  Feedback from Strategic Finances shows that this could be implemented by December 7th. We are working as hard as we can to complete it this year. Reach out to us for any questions.     Suggestion Box  Credits  Andrea Suarez produced this summary. Larry Wu produced this summary. Kunfu-po produced this summary. Everyone who spoke and presented on the call.

Episode #216: November 17th, 2022 | Editorial Summary  Agenda   0:00: Introduction  3:17: Votes and Polls  4:54: MIPs Update  9:15: Weekly Forum Recap  15:07: Initiative: Gasless Voting by DUX   37:41: Discussion: Recent Events & Impact on MakerDAO   1:21:39: Conclusion   Video Link  General Updates  Votes  Payton Rose 3:17 Visit: Voting Portal Next Week: No Planned Executive Proposal  Votes:   Polls: – 3:25   Executive Proposals: – 4:02     MIPs  Gala 4:54 Visit: Weekly MIPs Update #113 & MakerDAO Votes and Polls Public Calendar Important Dates: New proposals must be posted by Wednesday, December 7th, at the latest, to be eligible for the next monthly cycle.  Ratification Polls:   Top-Level MIPs – 5:20   Core Unit Budgets – 5:41   Miscellaneous – 6:03     Proposals in RFC:   Top-Level MIPs – 6:42   Miscellaneous – 7:12     Weekly Forum Recap  Artem Gordon 9:15  Visit: Weekly Forum Recap: November 10th - November 16th, 2022  Video: Link  News & Announcements:  Candidates for Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll Agreement between MakerGrowth and GnosisDAO    Discussion:  Endgame Plan Next Steps: 2023 Milestones for MetaDAO Launch Adjusting Dust Parameter (November 2022) Enabling the DSR New Silver Requesting Debt Ceiling Increase Calculating the Value of RWAs and the Surplus Buffer    Discussion  Initiative: Gasless Voting by DUX   Deniz 15:07  Contents:   Design Stage – 18:09   Live Demo – 21:02     Q&A 23:48   Payton Rose: Someone asks in Chat: how does the relayer know the voting power based on MKR?  25:11   Raphael Spannocchi: Is there a way to prevent misconduct such as duplicating votes by delegating and re-delegating the same MKR to different wallets or contracts?  27:10   Payton Rose: Doo, one of our Recognized Delegates, enjoyed the feature. Is this the first time it is live? How much usage have we seen?  29:27   Frank Cruz: Can you see what message you are signing? What are some of the attack factors that you might have thought of at the design stage?  32:30   Tim Schuppener: How many votes did you pre-fund?  34:14   Payton Rose: Deniz, can you tell us your perspective about how DUX pushed these changes to the Voting Portal? As the team responsible for these changes, what is your philosophy?   Discussion  Discussion: Recent Events & Impact on MakerDAO   Risk CU & Others 37:41  836×419 121 KB  38:33   Rema: I will speak on why we had the emergency executive vote. We are experiencing a crypto-centralized financial crisis that also impacts the DeFi ecosystem and permissionless actions to a certain extent. Some crypto projects, some even calling themselves DAOs, used FTX for custody. Due to fear and uncertainty, we might see large liquidations that will result in significant drops in prices. This will affect Maker…  48:43   Payton Rose: Patrick O’Donald asks in the chat what the impact on demand from borrowing from certain vaults is.  50:48  850×473 369 KB  52:43   Sebestien Derivaux: To answer the first question, Gemini is a trust and more secure than Circle. The main issue is that the funds would be frozen for some time.  To answer the second question, we have a PSM, but it still needs to be developed to dispose of GUSD. Deployment would take up to one week. It would take up to a few months to redeem our GUSD safely. Gemini does provide proof of reserve. The last report was in September.    57:46  847×477 275 KB  58:26   Sebestien Derivaux: These events won’t affect the implementation of MIP81. We have smart contracts that remove additional risk and allow for quick liquidation. Coinbase has ensured that they are top-notch custody.  1:01:21  849×474 345 KB    Payton Rose: Kianga from ArkInvest asks whether you can speak to the de-peg risks.  1:03:50   Payton Rose: What about USD, for example? We saw a lot of speculation on Twitter. What if people on Twitter gather up and try to sell in mass, and we say a de-peg on GUSD? What would be the protocol there?  1:05:51   Payton Rose: What risks does the protocol have, and what actions can we take to mitigate it?  1:08:44   Payton Rose: Do you have figures on how our value-at-risk compares to how it was a month ago?  1:17:45   Sebestien Derivaux: Regarding the last question, you have the vault type and the current situation. We always looked like debt weighted collateral ratio.  1:20:34  848×479 312 KB  Suggestion Box  Credits  Constanza produced this summary. Larry Wu produced this summary. Everyone who spoke and presented on the call.
